Geometric Distances in Feature Space

Source: R/bdiv_geometric.r
bdiv_geometric.Rd

This large and diverse family of metrics shares a common conceptual foundation: they treat each sample as a point in a multi-dimensional space, where each species represents an axis and its abundance is the coordinate on that axis. The dissimilarity between two samples is then calculated as the geometric distance between the two points.

Usage

bhattacharyya(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

canberra(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

chebyshev(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

chord(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

clark(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

gower(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

euclidean(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

hellinger(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

lorentzian(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

manhattan(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

matusita(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

minkowski(counts, power = 1.5, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

squared_chord(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

squared_euclidean(counts, pairs = NULL, cpus = n_cpus())

Arguments

counts

A numeric matrix of count data where each column is a sample, and each row is a feature. Any object coercible with as.matrix() can be given here, as well as phyloseq, rbiom, SummarizedExperiment, and TreeSummarizedExperiment objects.

pairs

Which combinations of samples should distances be calculated for? The default value (NULL) calculates all-vs-all. Provide a numeric or logical vector specifying positions in the distance matrix to calculate. See examples.

cpus

How many parallel processing threads should be used. The default, n_cpus(), will use all logical CPU cores.

power

Scaling factor for the magnitude of differences between communities (\(p\)). Default: 1.5

Value

A dist object.

Details

The Minkowski Family: Euclidean, Manhattan, and Chebyshev

The Minkowski distance is a generalized metric that encompasses several common distances as special cases. Its formula is:

$$D_{Minkowski} = \sqrt[p]{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - y_i)^p}$$

The parameter p controls the geometry of the space.

  • When \(p = 2\), it becomes the Euclidean distance, the familiar "straight-line" distance between two points. In ecology, the raw Euclidean distance is highly problematic because it is sensitive to the "double zero problem"—the shared absence of a species contributes nothing to the distance, but it is also sensitive to total abundance and can give misleading results when species are on different scales. The Squared Euclidean distance simply omits the final square root, which places even greater weight on large differences.

  • When \(p = 1\), it becomes the Manhattan distance (also known as City Block distance), which is the sum of the absolute differences along each axis. It is less sensitive to outliers than Euclidean distance. The Bray-Curtis dissimilarity is a normalized version of the Manhattan distance.

  • When \(p \rightarrow \infty\), it becomes the Chebyshev distance, which is simply the maximum absolute difference along any single axis. This metric is useful when a single large difference is more important than the sum of many small differences, such as in anomaly detection.

Weighted and Normalized Geometric Distances

Several metrics modify the basic geometric distances to make them more suitable for ecological data.

  • The Canberra distance is a weighted version of the Manhattan distance that is particularly sensitive to changes in values near zero. It divides the absolute difference for each species by the sum of their abundances, giving more weight to differences in rare species. However, this sensitivity can also amplify noise in sparse, low-count data.

  • The Clark's divergence distance is a related metric that can be seen as a squared version of the Canberra distance, averaged and then square-rooted, making it a type of root-mean-square Canberra distance.

Distances Based on Data Transformation

A powerful approach to overcoming the problems of the Euclidean distance is to transform the data before calculating the distance.

  • The Hellinger distance is the Euclidean distance calculated on data that has first been transformed to relative abundance and then square-root transformed. This transformation has the effect of down-weighting the influence of highly abundant species, making the Hellinger distance a robust quantitative metric that is less dominated by outliers than Bray-Curtis.

  • The Chord distance is the Euclidean distance calculated on data that has been normalized to unit length (i.e., each sample vector is projected onto the surface of a hypersphere). The Squared Chord distance is simply the square of this value and ranges from 0 to 2. Hellinger distance is equivalent to the Chord distance of square-root transformed data.

  • The Bhattacharyya and Matusita distances are related metrics that quantify the overlap between two probability distributions. When applied to species abundance vectors (treated as discrete probability distributions), they provide a robust measure of dissimilarity that, like Hellinger, is less sensitive to extreme abundance values.

Specialized Distances

  • The Gower distance is a flexible metric that averages the difference over all variables, with each term normalized by the range of that variable. This approach makes the Gower distance similar to the Manhattan distance but with range normalization included. It is a useful tool for creating a single distance matrix from a table of species abundance data.

  • The Lorentzian distance, derived from mathematical physics, is another specialized metric that can be used to alter the contribution of different features (species) to the overall distance, but its application in mainstream ecology is limited.

Calculation

Given:

  • \(P_i\): The proportional abundance of feature \(i\) in sample \(P\).

  • \(Q_i\): The proportional abundance of feature \(i\) in sample \(Q\).

  • \(n\): The number of features.

  • \(p\): For Minkowski only, the root/exponent to apply.

  • \(R_i\): For Gower only, the range of the \(i\)-th feature across all samples (max - min).

Bhattacharyya distancebhattacharyya()\(-\ln{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sqrt{P_i * Q_i}}\)
Canberra distancecanberra()\(\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{|P_i - Q_i|}{P_i + Q_i}\)
Chebyshev \(L_{\infty}\) distancechebyshev()\(\max(|P_i - Q_i|)\)
Chord distancechord()\(\sum_{i=1}^{n}|\sqrt{P_i} - \sqrt{Q_i}|\)
Clark's divergence distanceclark()\(\displaystyle \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\frac{P_i - Q_i}{P_i + Q_i}\right)^{2}}\)
Euclidean \(L_2\) distanceeuclidean()\(\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (P_i - Q_i)^2}\)
Gower distancegower()\(\displaystyle \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{|P_i - Q_i|}{R_i}\)
Hellinger distancehellinger()\(\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\sqrt{P_i} - \sqrt{Q_i})^{2}}\)
Lorentzian distancelorentzian()\(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\ln{(1 + |P_i - Q_i|)}\)
Manhattan \(L_1\) distancemanhattan()\(\sum_{i=1}^{n} |P_i - Q_i|\)
Matusita distancematusita()\(\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\sqrt{P_i} - \sqrt{Q_i}\right)^2}\)
Minkowski distance \(L_p\)minkowski()\(\sqrt[p]{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (P_i - Q_i)^p}\)
Squared Chord distancesquared_chord()\(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\sqrt{P_i} - \sqrt{Q_i}\right)^2\)
Squared Euclidean distancesquared_euclidean()\(\sum_{i=1}^{n} (P_i - Q_i)^2\)

References

Bhattacharyya, A. (1943). On a measure of divergence between two statistical populations defined by their probability distributions. Bulletin of the Calcutta Mathematical Society, 35, 99–109.

Cha, S.-H. (2007). Comprehensive survey on distance/similarity measures between probability density functions. International Journal of Mathematical Models and Methods in Applied Sciences, 1(4), 300–307.

Clark, P. J., & Evans, F. C. (1954). Distance to nearest neighbor as a measure of spatial relationships in populations. Ecology, 35(4), 445–453. doi:10.2307/1931034

Hellinger, E. (1909). Neue Begründung der Theorie quadratischer Formen von unendlichvielen Veränderlichen. Journal für die reine und angewandte Mathematik, 1909(136), 210–271. doi:10.1515/crll.1909.136.210

Minkowski, H. (1896). Geometrie der Zahlen. Teubner, Leipzig.

Gower JC (1971). A general coefficient of similarity and some of its properties. Biometrics, 27(4). doi:10.2307/2528823

Gower JC, Legendre P (1986). Metric and Euclidean Properties of Dissimilarity Coefficients. Journal of Classification, 3. doi:10.1007/BF01896809

Legendre P, Caceres M (2013). Beta diversity as the variance of community data: dissimilarity coefficients and partitioning. Ecology Letters, 16(8). doi:10.1111/ele.12141

Examples

    # Example counts matrix
    ex_counts
#>                   Saliva Gums Nose Stool
#> Streptococcus        162  793   22     1
#> Bacteroides            2    4    2   611
#> Corynebacterium        0    0  498     1
#> Haemophilus          180   87    2     1
#> Propionibacterium      1    1  251     0
#> Staphylococcus         0    1  236     1
    
    bhattacharyya(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_normalized(<environment>): could not find function "validate_normalized"
    
    canberra(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_normalized(<environment>): could not find function "validate_normalized"
    
    gower(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_normalized(<environment>): could not find function "validate_normalized"
    
    # Only calculate distances for A vs all.
    bhattacharyya(ex_counts, pairs = 1:3)
#> Error in validate_normalized(<environment>): could not find function "validate_normalized"
